Definition: A focal seizure that begins in one part of the body (e.g., hand or face) and spreads progressively to adjacent body parts, following the organization of the motor cortex. Named after neurologist John Hughlings Jackson.

A theory of emotion proposing that emotions arise from the perception of physiological responses to stimuli, rather than the other way around. For example, we feel sad because we cry, rather than crying because we feel sad.

A brainstem reflex in which tapping the chin causes contraction of the masseter muscle and elevation of the mandible. Used clinically to assess the function of cranial nerve V (trigeminal nerve) and brainstem integrity.

A measure of variability in the timing of successive action potentials or synaptic transmission, often assessed in single-fiber electromyography (EMG). Increased jitter can indicate neuromuscular junction disorders.

The c-Jun N-terminal kinase pathway, a signaling cascade involved in cellular responses to stress, including apoptosis, inflammation, and cytokine production. Implicated in neurodegeneration and brain injury.

A rare genetic disorder characterized by abnormal development of the cerebellum and brainstem, leading to developmental delays, breathing abnormalities, abnormal eye movements, and ataxia. The 'molar tooth sign' on MRI is diagnostic.

A type of cell-cell communication that requires direct contact between signaling and receiving cells, often through membrane-bound ligands and receptors. Important in neural development and synapse formation.
A subdivision of the inferior cerebellar peduncle that carries vestibular afferents to the cerebellum, particularly to the flocculonodular lobe. Important for balance and eye movement coordination.

A structure at synapses or cell-cell junctions comprising multiple protein assemblies that maintain adhesion and communication. In neurons, includes tight junctions, adherens junctions, and gap junctions.
